awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploring Organizational Configuration as a Design Lever
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this EArly Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to explore the mechanisms through which different organizational structures drive design decisions in the research and development of complex technological systems.  The study leverages a unique natural experiment that enables the first direct empirical comparison of the multi-decade evolution of two functionally identical systems, developed separately under different organizational structures. Although significant prior research has examined both the fit between technical and organizational architectures, and the implications of different technical architectures for system lifecycle properties, the question of how technical-organizational "fit" can drive desirable design outcomes remains unexplored. To answer this question, rich process data on the sequence of events, actions and decisions that describe the parallel development processes will be collected. The data includes (1) in-depth interviews with each of the key contributors, (2) proposals and progress reports written on a near annual basis, (3) design documents, (4) press releases and (5) journal articles capturing key outcomes. The data will be analyzed using a process tracing approach, enabling a link to the underlying mechanisms driving each design decision to the structure of the context of the corresponding technical and organizational architectures.   

If successful, the insights from this work have the potential to be transformative in that they will characterize organizational configuration as a new design lever; this could enable engineering organizations to harness research outputs more effectively and influence the structure of the technology they produce. In addition, this work has direct implications for current space policy debates on the role of centralized investment in technology development and industrial policy. In that context, prior work by the PI has been presented, at the request of executive-level officials, at both the European Space Agency (ESA) and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). More broadly, on-the-ground scientific data, on the actual design process, in real design organization, is the foundation for a revolution in the science of design engineering. These insights could yield advances in innovation productivity that will substantially accelerate the national (and global) economy.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal aimed to explore the mechanisms through which different organizational structures drive design decisions in the research and development of complex technological systems.  The study leveraged a unique natural experiment – whereby two space agencies spent more than a decade developing the same science instrument technology in near isolation from each other – to directly observe how organizational structure impacts design. Although significant prior research has examined both the fit between technical and organizational architectures, and the implications of different technical architectures for system lifecycle properties, the question of how technical-organizational “fit” can drive desirable design outcomes remains underexplored. To answer this question, we collected rich process data on the sequence of events, actions and decisions that describe the parallel development processes. The data includes (1) in-depth interviews with each of the key contributors, (2) proposals and progress reports written on a near annual basis, (3) design documents, (4) press releases and (5) journal articles capturing key outcomes. The data was analyzed using a process tracing approach, enabling us to link the underlying mechanisms driving each design decision to the structure of the context of the corresponding technical and organizational architectures.   

The study found that multiple technical, organizational and political factors affected how scientists and technologists made design decisions, and also what they saw as the decision to be made. We tracked the strength of the influence of these factors on each decision and showed how the relative importance depended on the level of the decision within the system architecture. Although we might have expected higher-level decisions to be more affected by the politics of space, in fact, political influences like apparent incentives to collaborate with new member states permeated to low levels of design (e.g., the decision to use particular multiplexing readout scheme was strongly influenced by national priorities). Overall, considering more than 40 decisions, we found a high level of constraint on most decisions, with outcomes at least partially pre-determined by previously made organizational choices.

This work highlights a potential role for organizational design as an effective design lever and explains how this lever can operate; this could enable engineering organizations to harness research outputs more effectively and influence the structure of the technology they produce. Further, it showed how process tracing methods – common in organizational theory – can be applied to gain insight into the design process.  In addition, this work has direct implications for current space policy debates on the role of centralized investment in technology development and industrial policy. In addition to typical scholarly outputs, results have been presented, at the request of executive-level officials, at both ESA and NASA and the data products created – in the form of technology development histories – have been made freely available.
